body.raw:
##### Building and Flying FPV Drones    
When I first started building my own FPV drone, I quickly realized it was more than just putting parts together, it was a mix of electronics, mechanics, and software tuning. I had to choose the right components: a sturdy frame, a flight controller with the right firmware (I went with Betaflight), ESCs that could handle my motor’s power, and a video system that wouldn’t introduce too much latency. Soldering was a skill I had to pick up fast since proper wiring is crucial for a stable build. Once everything was assembled, I spent hours in Betaflight configuring my flight controller, calibrating the sensors, and tweaking PID settings to make sure my drone wouldn’t just flip over the moment I tried to take off.
 
Flying an FPV drone was a completely different challenge. Unlike regular drones with GPS stabilization, my quad relied entirely on my inputs, and every mistake meant a crash. Before taking it outside, I spent a lot of time in a simulator to build muscle memory, getting used to controlling throttle, yaw, pitch, and roll simultaneously. The first real flights were nerve-wracking, but also a lot of fun. I had to learn about video transmission, ensuring my antennas were positioned correctly, and staying within legal frequency and power limits. I also had to be mindful of weather conditions and make sure my fail-safes were set up properly in case of signal loss. Every flight taught me something new, and while the crashes were frustrating, the thrill of flying through my goggles made all the effort worth it.
